20050732.review:
It's taken me a while to write this review. Mainly because it's hard for me to put my feelings about this game into words (also I'm lazy). I will admit it, I fucking cried at the ending. And let me tell you, I rarely cry at this sort of sentimentality. 

Planetarian ~the reverie of a little planet~ is about the Junker and his meeting with Yumeni, an android left behind to care for a planetarian within an abandoned city. Everyday she does the same thing, she heads outside, even when admist acid rain, and tries forlornly to attract customers. Her one companion is Miss Jena, a broken projector. When the Junker visits the Planetarian in the hopes of loot, he encounters Yumeni, who claims he is their 2,500,000th customer. The Junker agrees to fix 'Miss Jena' in the promise of seeing their show. What follows is a tear-jerker of a VN about a robot who's only wish is for heaven to not be split between machines and humans, and a man who learns to dream of stars.

The story is set in a dystopian world, where nuclear war has left humanity in ruin and leaves the ever-present 'Rain', acid rain as a side-effect of the nuclear fallout. The few humans that survived are hunted by automated robots that act as if the world never ended, killing any human they detect. Some people act as scavengers, referred to in-universe as 'Junkers', of which the MC of Planetarian is one.

Get it. Just get it. It's a masterpiece. The soundtrack ranges from the beautiful and dreamy, to the slow and melancholic. The artists did an excellent job capturing the dystopian feel and bringing characters to life (although it is a bit dated in terms of fidelity. Keep in mind however that it was originally released in 2004). It's brilliant and worth every penny. £6.99 is well worth this title.

Congratulations Key on making me cry my eyes out. 

And also, fuck you for making me feel. 

Some notes:
Play time of about 3 hours (I do play through VNs slowly however)
Steam version doesn't come with the soundtrack for personal use (you will have to be content with youtube or other means i.e. Itunes unfortunately :( then again I didn't try that hard apart from a quick internet search)
Voice acting is available, however I didn't play with them on so I am unaware how good they are
No fan service or NSFW content in any shape or form

Now if you'll excuse me, I'm going to sit in the corner and cry after remembering the ending [spoiler]You were never broken Yumeni. We're the ones that are broken[/spoiler]

PS apologies for the shite review. I'm pretty lame at this kind of thing but I need to get my feelings about this game across before I explode from the feels. Feel free to send your complaints concerning the poor quality of this review [url=https://www.google.co.uk/maps/place/Avondale+Environmental+Ltd/@55.990329,-3.678437,15z/data=!4m2!3m1!1s0x0:0xfbea3d28a06fc71e]here[/url].

19510228.review:
Once again, Key brings us a visual novel that just shoots you with an arrow, straight through the heart. I would strongly reccomend this to both new and experienced VN readers. (Also, the Japanese version is available when you buy the game on steam, if you can read Japanese characters. The language can be changed in the game's prefrences by right clicking it.) 

Its about a 4-5 hour read if you like to listen to the dialouge, and maybe about 2 and a half hours if you skip most of it. The music is ok, its nothing amazing, the CG and backgrounds are fairly decent, but what makes this game is the story and the writing. Honestly, I just burst out crying at the end. It is such a powerful and beautiful story that everyone should read. Honestly, this is just incredible. My rating of the title is 9/10. The only reason it doesnt score a perfect 10 is the repetative music and sound effects. Honestly, some more work could have been done there to further justify this otherwise stunning and incredible story. 

A little about the story: 
This short novel set in a post apocalyptic earth, tells the story of a "junker", who meets a half broken robot in a long abandoned planetarium. There, seeking refuge from the never ending, radioactive "rain" and lethal murderous robots, he happens to enter during the one week of the year which the robot is functunal. Bad luck? Faith? Regardless of the reason, the robot, Hoshino Yumemi, (ほしのゆめみ), tries to do her job and show him the stars. But the big telescope inside the planetarium is broken after 30 years of not being used. In the abandoned and worn down planetarium, in a broken world, he decides to stay and try to fix the telescope...

Do you like reading? If so, cool, keep reading my review to get a better idea as to whether or not this game is for you. If not, then this game likely isn't for you. This is a Visual Novel; Visual Novels are basically novels with pictures that have voice acting, music, sounds, and in a lot of cases, choices for you to make. 

In regards to planetarian ~the reverie of a little planet~, it is a Visual Novel in all of the above ways except that you don't get to make choices, however, if you look at it as a novel with voice acting and music, then you might find it super attractive for its price tag. How many books can you buy that has different voice actors for different roles, sounds and music (audio-books, I guess, but for this price)? 

If I am having trouble convincing you, then I have this to say: “Key wrote it”. Key is a company that writes Visual Novels and produces Anime, both are positively received. What makes Key so great, in my humble opinion, is  that  they make fun, beautiful, and heart-breaking stories- particularly the last bit- such as Clannad and Angel Beats! which are Anime and Visual Novels themselves. 

So, if a post-apocalyptic setting, robots, and a heartwarming, but tear-jerking story appeals to you, then I recommend picking this up.

19352665.review:
我承认我并没有真的在Steam上玩过《星之梦》，或者，不如说，我买来本来就不是为了“玩”的。

没错，我是说，还债，以及为了能有这么一个写测评的机会。

第一次玩这游戏，还是在我穿军装的那个时候。当时正服现役的我，周末唯一的娱乐，也不过就是用PSP听听歌，玩一些休闲得几乎毫无尿点可言的游戏，比如说数独之类……（据说男兵那边联机玩怪物猎人的很多，然而我并不喜欢）为了不至于让军营把自己关成傻子，我订阅了不少二次元类的刊物，其中就有那么一本，叫做《PSPe族》。

有一次，一期e族上简单介绍了《星之梦》，还在光盘里附带了汉化的ISO。由于很眼缘这部作品的画风，所以就跑去司务长那边用她的电脑把这个ISO拷进了PSP。当时我的想法是，就当个消遣时的电子小说看吧，反正GAL什么的我历来不感冒。然后，我也就这么抱着这种想法进了游戏。

作为一个GAL，或者说，不管作为一个什么游戏，仅仅2个小时就会结束的流程实在是太短了点。可是，当最后结束之后，我才发现我的眼泪居然滴满了屏幕。本来我还觉得，在部队四年多的磨练，早就让我的泪腺和落寞伤感的神经变得麻木不仁，只有我读完整篇《星之梦》之后，我才惊觉，其实我根本什么都没改变。去掉那层战斗机器的外壳，我仍旧还是那个细腻，脆弱，容易哭的小女孩。

善良、纯白、闪耀人性的光芒；这些词语放在星野梦美身上，再恰当不过。也正是这些东西，拂去了拾荒者心灵的蒙尘，让他得以再次懂得什么叫人性。然而这好不容易开出的美丽璀璨的花朵，却在机动兵器的炮火下被摧残得体无完肤。

[spoiler]『如果……无论如何……都要召唤我……到天堂去的话，……客人……我请求您……请不要将天堂……分开，……请不要……将人与机器人的天堂……分开……我想永远……永远……为了人们而……』[/spoiler]

——这到底是为什么？

——为什么要把这么美好的东西当着读者的面毫不留情地撕碎？

——为什么，这明明是人性中最灿烂的宝物，在暴力前却如此脆弱而不堪一击？

或许，我的想法只能用三句经典台词来形容。

[quote=FALLOUT] “War, war never changes.”[/quote]

[quote=CALL OF DUTY 4: MODERN WARFARE] “In modern war, you will die like a dog for no good reason.” [/quote]

[quote=THIS WAR OF MINE] “This Fucking War.”[/quote]

但是这些闪光的珍宝，难道仅仅因为它们在战争和杀戮前弱不禁风就毫无价值吗？不，不是的。正因为脆弱，易碎，所以这人性的光芒才更加珍贵。[b]人所以为人，正是因为有了这些光芒，才区别于野兽。而很不幸的是，许多人的所作所为，甚至不如这个叫做“星野梦美”的、用着蹩脚逻辑系统的机器人AI，不管是虚拟空间，还是现实。[/b]在这光芒面前，即使强大如英克雷，兄弟会，NCR，也一样渺小得如同蝼蚁般不值一提。

[h1]我们到底是从何时，不再抬头仰望那璀璨的星空？
我们到底是从何时，不再低头沉思那匆忙的人生？[/h1]

梦美和拾荒者，他们的故事或许不该称之为悲剧，尽管他们已双双魂归天际。倒不如说，污秽不堪的废土，承载不起这两颗纯净如水晶的灵魂，所以他们选择了离开。[h1]但愿，在那天堂里，这两颗皎白的灵魂能够获得安宁。天堂里，有爱着他们的好人，有用之不尽的替换部品，有无数的机器人伙伴，唯独没有的，是丑恶不堪的战争。[/h1]

……

直到现在，《星之梦》的故事，对我产生的影响仍然是深刻的。我在辐射系列里一直坚持的圣母路线，也充满着满满的《星之梦》风格。我也期望着，某一天，当我在废土的某个都市里找到一所天文馆，走进去时，会听到那个熟悉的声音……

[h1]『欢迎大家光临天象馆，这里有着无论何时都决不会消失的，美丽的无穷光辉，满天的星星们在等待着大家的到来……』[/h1]

Above all, JUST SHUT UP AND TAKE MY MONEY AND TEAR.

19338071.review:
Planetarian is a great kinetic novel, the first kinetic i have ever played actually (odd considering i have played lots of visual novels with multiple routes).  Just a note though, the game is fairly old so consider this when it's 'style' doesn't quite feel that of modern key games (Also, don't be put off by this, whilst it's slightly older than say Rewrite, little busters, clannad ect, the story telling is still just as great).

The game tells a great story set in a a world which is essentially dead, It will develop a unique meeting of a person who happened upon a robot in the planetarian, the story will take you through their meeting and the robots love for stars, to explain how the world is how it is and how she became to be alone, forever waiting the return of the staff and customers. The story telling is really top notch, for only two real characters, you never feel your missing anything, they have great interactions and her becomes to enjoy the robot being around. Of course this is Key, anyone who knows key probably knows it will be sad, so i wont touch to heavy there as i don't want to ruin it, just expect to feel sad with the end developments. 

All in all, the game is amazing, it's a short 4 hour average play (might be a little less if you are quick reading and skip some voice, a litte longer on auto play) but it's worth every second with amazing story telling and emotional impact
10/10 easy

19305906.review:
Planetarian – короткая и трогательная история в постапокалиптическом мире. Новелла цепляет с первых минут и не отпускает до самого конца. 

Фоновая музыка позитивно-мечтательная под стать главной героине. Композиций не так много, но атмосферу задают хорошо и надоесть не успевают. Графическая составляющая средненькая, все-таки чувствуется, что новелла уже не нова, но общей картины это все не портит.

Новелла линейна и имеет всего одну концовку, относить это к плюсам или минусам каждый решит для себя сам. Сюжетная часть хороша, каких-либо серьезных дыр не заметил, вселенная более-менее проработана, герои располагают к себе и заставляют сопереживать.

Что самое важное – Planetarian дает пищу для размышлений, хотя в век конвеерных блек опсов и ассасинов, новелла просто останется незамеченной, как бы печально это не звучало.

19258925.review:
Planetarian is an interesting game. It was my first entry into the VN genre, and as a kinetic novel, having only one route, it provides a simple, easy to understand and unfortunately brief experience. As a VN by Key, it boasts superb writing and amazing storytelling, even if the presentation is a bit dated. While the $10 price tag may be a bit steep for the short length of the game, it is incredibly potent and an interesting tale that questions what it means to be human, isolation, and companionship. The two characters are excellent foils, and you can see them play off of each other as the story develops. Overall, it may not be the most polished or modern VN, but it has a huge (robotic) heart.

10/10.

19146514.review:
[h1]«Звёздная мечта»[/h1]

Достаточно короткая визуальная новелла без всякой интерактивности и выбора, в которой доступно только пассивное чтение в авторежиме или самостоятельное перелистывание слайдов, но при этом с сильной историей, проникающей вглубь и затрагивающая струнки души.

События «игры» разворачиваются на территории когда-то оживлённого города, ныне Мёртвой зоны, покинутого людьми и в завершении разбитого биохимическими боеголовками. Нет больше солнечного света, нет возможности увидеть в ночном небе звёзды... Льёт только непрекращающийся Дождь. 

На протяжении всей новеллы будут строиться отношения между безымянным героем-пессимистом (Старьёвщик) и девочкой, излучающей безграничный оптимизм, которую он встретил в давно заброшенном здании с построенным наверху Планетарием. Чем она ему поможет и как он ей расскажет о настоящем? Поверит ли она его словам? Оставит её или заберёт с собой? Но Хосино Юмеми, сама того не зная, сыграет важную роль для будущего Старьёвщика: она покажет тот мир, который человечество потеряло, тем самым изменив мировоззрение у парня и даст толчок к появлению в его жизни важной миссии.

«Весь небосвод со всеми звёздами ожидает вас».

P.S. Пожалуйста, берегите нашу планету.

18007225.review:
Rewriting this because I think some things need cleared up a bit for people not familiar with this sort of story...Key's storys have a tendency to give you excruciating detail into characters and backgrounds.(more below)

Nothing negative to say about this game for my own part. It was one of the rare gems I've seen in recent years and is a strong pull of Quality over Quantity (as per hours of play). I never would have heard about this had it not been for the Steam sale, but it would be well worth even the full price at $9.99 (if you can justify going to a movie theatre, this game is worth at least as much).

Important things to note:
~This "game" is basically a short book. No choices, to make beside whether to click ahead or listen through a scene.
~There is a lot of detailed description. Some people might find it to be too much, but given that the entirety of the story takes place in less than a week's time for the character, it is necessary. By the end of it you should have a good grasp on the world, the main characters as well as the world's history that brought it to the present state. If you find yourself in any way clueless it's probably an error on your own ability to read and understand.
~The story is emotionally driven primarilly. 
If you're action oritented, look elsewhere. 
If you need something that aims to grip you quickly, look elsewhere.
~Full appreciation will come from not having a standard set in your mind for things to be like in real life as it is now. Consider the world that the story is in.




_______________________
Read through this story twice now and enjoyed it as much as the first time. Even knowing everything that's going to happen, the music and atmosphere that they created still hits hard at all the right points.

17939750.review:
As far as I remember, I don't think I've ever cried in response to any piece of media. Sure, I had started to tear up of a few times here and there, but never actually cried. I've just finished this game. That statement is no longer true.

I can't really say too much without venturing into spoilers, but... Despite the borderline winge-worthy opening, man. That story developed into something absolutely fantastic and well told. 
It got particularly deep, too. I can't mention my best example without spoilers, but... For my second best, I'm sure I'll be having an internal discussion with myself about the idea of humans, a race with rather questionable moral system, assigning one to androids.

P.S. If you launch the game, when it informs you that you're missing the MS Gothic font (which is the font that was intended to be used to consume this game) and asks you to select one from a list, presuming that you are running any remotely recent OS, you probably already have it. Just look through the list of fonts it presents you with and it should be there. If it's not, enable and install the keyboard for Japanese, that should fix it.

17923304.review:
A decent VN by Key that tells you the story of post-apocalypse world where humanity destroy themselves with their technology and what happens inside a planetarium between a robot and a scavenger guy. In this game, the story was divided into 2 parts : inside the planetarium and outside.

The inside was the introduction part where the narator explained the condition of the world, how he got winded there and how he was baffled to meet the robot-girl. But somehow after that, this part is quite boring and dull. The outside part was more interesting part for me personally and I quite enjoyed it throughout until the ending. (although the ending was 'hanging'). After finishing the game, I looked up the audio CDs that were put up in youtube though so I already watched the full ending, which I recommend you to do it also.

So for the conclusion, I do recommend this game for you people who enjoyed 'science fiction' type stories albeit it has some flaws. The game is still very enjoyable and the 'missing part' of the games can be searched using google. My rating : 7/10

17882254.review: I saw this as I was browsing through the depths of Steam's store and picked it up on a whim. Right after I purchased it, I began reading through this visual novel which was made by 'Key', the same studio behind many great visual novels and anime including 'Clannad' and 'Angel Beats!'. The first half or so seems to be dragged out quite a bit with banter between the narrator and a robot named Yumemi Hoshino. I became mainly enthralled with the concept of the setting, a post-apocalytpic world that has been occupied by war machines. The game features excellent artwork and music composition. The ending, much like in Key fashion, ripped my heart out and tore my soul asunder. If you are a fan of kinetic visual novels, or even slightly interested in visual novels as is, I extremely recommend that you purchase it. It'll only last you a few hours, but the experience will hopefully last with you for a good long while like it has with myself.

17594023.review: This is my first time writing a review for a game on steam, but seeing as I just finished it I'll keep it short and sweet. This visual novel surpassed my expectations in almost every way. I did'nt think I was going to cry as much as I did and despite taking around 5 hours to complete I felt like it had an intense emotional impact on me. The voice acting and music are stellar, and truthfully this visual novel would not feel right any other way. The art is beautiful, and makes great use of rain animations for added effect of a world that is 'broken'. The plot/story is 10/10, the fact that it is so short is half of what makes this visual novel so tragic, and I can't explain any further because of spoilers. The only notable characters are Mr. Customer and Yumemi, and luckily they are both voice acted because their conversations range from witty, to perverted, to depressing, to hungry (this game made me hungry, don't ask why). I bought this game on sale for $5, but now I feel like I should have payed $10 due to the high quality of the sound and visuals. A mini-masterpiece, and worth every tear that I shed.

Het verhaal heeft eigenlijk maar twee characters in zich en dar is de Junker van uit dat oogpunt kijk jij en een robot genaamd Yumemi.
Dit verhaal is te zien/lezen binnen 5 a 6 uurtjes en gaf bij mij in het begin een beetje het gevoel van in wat voor een visual novel ben ik nu weer beland maar naar een klein uurtje bezig te zijn zat ik er een maal in.
De Junker wie een overelevende is treed in stad binnen waar geen leven meer te vinden is om zo de schatten te bemagtigen die daar 30 jaar geleden zijn achter gelaten voor de oorlog.
Hier bij praten we over de maar meest simpele dingen om te overleven.
Na een bepaalde tijd bereikt hij het centrum van de stad waar hij voor zich zelf dacht een millitair gebouw te betreden maar waar hij uiteindelijk belande in een planetarium daar loopt hij Yumemi tegen het lijf.
Zij wacht al 30 jaar op bezoekers en is uiteraard hartstikke enthousiast wanneer ze haar eerste bezoeker ziet.
dit al met al zorgt voor een leuk en vermakelijk verhaaltje waar in ik aantal keren heb moeten lachen om de typische japanse humor.
Het verhaal heeft aan het einde ook nog zo zijn emtionele kant waardoor ik in tranen uitbarste.
Ik zelf vond het een heel mooi verhaal en heb me er wel mee vermaakt die aantal uren ik zelf heb het verdeeld over 2 a 3 dagen en zal over een bepaalde tijd zo weer het verhaal tevoorschijn halen. 
In het spel heb je trouwens ook nog een music mode dat je toestaat de muziek te beluisteren wat is gebruikt in het spel  en een modus waar in je die achtergronden kunt zien die ze hebben gebruikt als her weergave.
Verder ik weet niet zo wat de prijs nu is op steam maar ik heb de game in een sale gehaald dacht ik maar kan me zo hugen dat ik toender tijd er 10 a 15 euro heb voor betaald wat voor mij tedoen was.
De game voor mij was een dikke plus.

17482494.review:
"It's okay, I'm just a little broken."

Murderously, shamelessly, violently heartbreaking. And, thinking like a robot tends to think in this story, does not care how hard you're crying, because that's what it's programmed to do. It can be reckless like that.

That's what the game was programmed to do. That's the only thing it's supposed to do. It's the only thing it can do. It doesn't even understand why you would object to it making you cry. Because it's a bargain model and does not have that feature.

As you might expect from other reviews, this story (of course it's from Key, who else would write something like this and release it for other people to experience), no matter how much of a jaded bastard you think you are, who never is moved by fiction--much less sci-fi, post-apocalyptic fiction, because everyone's done that already--will happily welcome you in and test that cute little theory you have.

It'll break you, but just a little bit. You'll still be able to function at work/school/violently sobbing on the floor of the bathroom tomorrow.

17374865.review:
Just finished Planetarian and thought I'd write a quick review for those considering it. I am not particularly into visual novels (I think this is the only one I've finished), so I can't really compare it to others. While the game feels padded with some unnecessary repetition at different points, it moved me like a video game hasn't moved me before. For some reason I can't explain, I really cared for the characters by the end (no, I'm not going to spoil anything). Part of it might the music, which I felt was superb.

Conclusion: I definitely recommend it if you are looking for a thought-provoking and emotional story. Be aware that it's a visual novel, so you make no choices and there is no "failure state." I'd also suggest doing it in one go (took me about four hours) for full effect.

17373994.review: Well, as someone who has never played (if you can call a "kinetic novel" playing) anything by Key before, I didn't quite know what was in store for me. It looked cute. There was a good deal. Why not? I didn't know I was going to end up crying. Multiple times. Set in a post-apocalyptic world, the narrator is a "Junker" who goes through old scrap to survive in a deadly world where other living people are few and far between and unlikely to be friendly. He encounters a robot who was left behind in a planetarium 30 years ago when the war broke out and who has no idea nobody is ever coming back for her or will ever visit the planetarium again. If that premise isn't depressing enough, it's all downhill from there. But was it worth it? Absolutely. Somehow the writers are able to pluck out just the right refrains to repeat, the right choice of words to tug at your proverbial heart strings at the right moments. Assuming you enjoy a sad story every now and again, this is absolutely worth your time.

17290320.review:
Planetarian is a commentary on the future of human kind.  It is a work that is meant to entice our inner humanity towards ideas about war and peace.  Planetarian uses juxtaposition in order to contrast the dirt and filth of war and hatred with the purity of human ideology.  It is a harrowing reminder of the kind of world we could push ourselves into, and it is also a sign of hope that our world has yet to see such a terrible fate.

I was surprised to see that this version actually voices the junker and all of the other miscellaneous characters.  The additional voices were fitting for the story, and managed to evoke emotions even more so than the first time I read through this.

16246214.review:
This was my first experience with a visual novel, and I really enjoyed it. The content was amazing and I cried many manly tears, but since this format was new to me and may be to others looking at this title, I'd like to do a quick rundown on the experience from a more technical standpoint.

First, I've heard that some visual novels have branching story lines, mini games, and animation. Planetarian has none of these things, so feel free to set the auto advance to the speed you like and sit back for however long you have. I had the settings almost as fast as they go and it took about 4 hours from start to finish. Setting the auto-advance also means you won't accidentally skip any voiced lines that have a pause before they play on a slide.

There's enough text that the overall feeling was somewhere between reading a book and watching a movie. Mostly the narration is left out, but occasional character lines are not voiced. There are maybe 10 backgrounds and 30 character pictures that are shuffled around throughout the story, and while they're appealing enough, you really have to be engaged with the text or you won't enjoy yourself.

Basically, this isn't a game, but I liked it. Consider watching it with friends on a TV if you want to get a little more out of the purchase.

Oh, and there are a few minor errors in the translation, but they weren't distracting and the meaning was intact.

16127084.review:
Like many reviews for other visual novels on Steam suggest, make sure you have some tissues ready before you start.

Unlike those games, however, you won't be using them to masturbate.

If you're familiar with Key's other works (Clannad, Little Busters, Angel Beats, so on...), you should already know what you're getting into. It doesn't have [url=http://i.imgur.com/umUypn1.png]the amazing character art that we've all come to love and expect from Key[/url], but I guess the one character in the game doesn't look all that bad, so I guess it's okay. In terms of audio, there were a few moments I was tempted to mute or lower the volume from just being slightly annoyed by it, but otherwise the soundtrack was pretty nice to listen to, and I felt it fit well with the rest of the game.

But it's not the visuals or soundtrack that's the most important, you play a visual novel for the writing. While I felt some parts dragged on a bit too long, the overall story was short enough that I think it can be excused for that. When playing English translations of Japanese visual novels, it's common to see words cutting off at the end of the line or needing a second page to finish a sentence. I only noticed this happening once throughout the game.

If you've already experienced and enjoyed any of Key's other works, then you already know this game is worth getting. If not, I guess a good place to start would be the Angel Beats anime series. It's 13 episodes long and free to legally watch on [url=http://www.crunchyroll.com/angel-beats/videos]Crunchyroll[/url].

16021399.review:
I'm back.
入宅作。十年间，从完全不会日文到如今开始在字幕组和汉化组里干活，从各种意义上的中二少年到如今至少稍微好了那么一点点，[strike]从不明白为啥要买正版到如今看见日呆游戏就想+1，[/strike]总之十年不见后，我变了很多……

抱歉，评测区并不是抒发个人经历的地方。来谈谈这个游戏吧。

KEY社。入了ACG坑的人，不知道这个名字的或许凤毛麟角吧。毋庸置疑，它是开创了GALGAME界一个时代的公司，也是泣系游戏的鼻祖级公司。相对于LB和Rewrite的褒贬不一，[strike]智代AFTER被不少人称作雷作[/strike]，KEY社旧作的风评几乎是一水的好评。——不过就个人来说，以上提到的这些作品我依然玩得挺带劲。

貌似春夏秋冬四大名著是国内独有的说法？春之CL，夏之AIR，秋之ONE，冬之Kanon。
我一直觉得Key社的作品充满了正能量。他们擅长写鸿篇巨著，能将一个非常巨大的故事处理得井井有条。这点在CLANNAD上得到了最佳体现。CLANNAD在国内的译名蛮多的，我见过一个不太常见的“人生”。明明CLANNAD和人生在意译角度上八竿子打不着，但阅读完成后仍能了解到这个译名因何而来。不只是一部视觉小说，确实就是人生啊。

KEY社的作品普遍感觉是前期轻松明快，中期面临困境，后期泪点爆发。那么把平常需要10小时甚至更长时间的泪点压缩到2小时会怎样？压缩催泪弹，正是这个planetarian。

当年躺在床上半夜对着NDS点击着屏幕，看到天象仪映出的星空突然泪流满面。在被毁灭的世界中，天象馆在那一刻成了世外桃源。前期明明是那么轻松愉快的展开，但剧情却莫名地开始急转直下，一个又一个剧情的爆发把我打得溃不成军。从那以后我就牢牢记住了KEY社这个名字，并从此一发不可收拾地走上了ACG的不归路。

对于Steam版，首先英文翻译……说好听点就是见仁见智吧。身经百战的诸君大概也明白日呆、小说、文字向被翻译成英文以后大概是个什么样子。翻译者的辛劳我是明白的，但……咳咳。

还好，你可以选择原生日版。在库里右键点击游戏 - 属性 - 语言，可以更改语言。但是这就迎来了另一个问题：[h1]右键菜单乱码[/h1]。我使用了LE转区，然而无效。或许NTLEA或App能正常些？我并没有试，不过就算不使用右键菜单也并不怎么影响游戏：[h1]主菜单和正文都正常。[/h1]

总结起来：[h1]对中文操作系统支持不完美。但是游戏本身的素质是值得买的。[/h1]
最后还是姑且提醒一句：[h1]这是全年龄视觉小说，请不要以各种意义上的“怎么不能战斗”给它差评。[/h1]

PS：感觉星之梦挺适合出个剧场版动画，可惜并没有。

------------------

15890631.review:
planetarian ~the reverie of a little planet~ ist ein Titel im Sortiment von Sekai Project und es ist zwar schon seit einiger Zeit möglich, planetarian auf englisch zu lesen, allerdings erscheint dank Sekai Project nun die erste offizielle Version auf dem internationalen Markt.

[quote]Titel: planetarian ~the reverie of a little planet~
    Entwickler: VisualArt’s/Key
    Genre: Kinetic Novel, Drama
    Länge: 2-10h
    Premiere: 29.11.2004 (Japan) / 12.09.2014 (Englisch / Steam)

    Story:
    Why don’t you come to the planetarium?
    The beautiful twinkling of eternity that will never fade, no matter what.
    All the stars in the sky are waiting for you.

    In time for the 10th anniversary since it’s original release in Japan, planetarian is an engaging and emotional visual novel from legendary studio VisualArt’s/Key’s KineticNovel brand. For the first time ever, this memorable title is available on Steam in English!

    Set in a post-apocalyptic world, what remains of humanity survive where biochemical warheads have destroyed civilization and endless “Rain” continues to fall upon the shattered earth. Autonomous battle drones continue a fight that has long lost it’s meaning. As a junker, a scavenger who seeks out undamaged items of value, you end up in a domed building that appears to be a military installation.

    That building turns out to be a planetarium and in there you meet a young woman named Yumemi. A member of the help staff at the planetarium, she’s been waiting for customers to visit for over thirty years. It is this chance encounter with Yumemi that even the coldest of hearts may be thawed.[/quote]

[h1]Handlung:[/h1]

Die Handlung ist, wie man es eigentlich von VisualArt’s/Key Visual Novels kennt: Es fängt alles recht interessant an und man wird ziemlich schnell in die Geschichte hinein gezogen. Wie dies hier aber auch typisch ist, hat man es auch ruckzuck mit Drama zu tun. Die Handlung ist insgesamt recht kurz, trotzdem trifft einen der Verlauf dann doch schon irgendwie. Leute, die lieber alles Friede, Freude, Eierkuchen haben möchten, sollten schon allein bei dem Setting die Finger von der Visual Novel lassen.

Da es sich bei planetarian um eine Kinetic Novel handelt, ist diese komplett gradlinig. Es gibt keine Entscheidungsmöglichkeiten und technisch gesehen bekommt man die Geschichte einfach nur mit ein paar Hintergrund- und Charakterbildern erzählt. Da es aber eh nur zwei Charaktere gibt und man die Geschichte nicht in mehrere Routen aufteilen muss, ist dies nicht weiter störend.

[h1]Illustrationen:[/h1]

Die Visual Novel ist mit dem Erscheinungsdatum von 2004 nun schon etwas älter und dementsprechend sind die Illustrationen nun auch schon ein bisschen betagter. Trotzdem ist Yumemi sehr ansprechend dargestellt und auch die Hintergrundbilder sind auch für die heutige Zeit in Ordnung. Klar muss man da wegen dem Alter ein paar Abstriche machen, dies mindert aber keineswegs die Qualität der Novel.

Was allerdings etwas störend ist, ist die Farbwahl der Schriftfarbe. Weiß auf schwarz ist den Großteil der Novel kein Problem. Irgendwann wird allerdings der schwarze Untergrund eine Zeit weggelassen und der Text so auf die Illustrationen gelegt. Hier wird der Text dann an manchen Stellen recht unleserlich und man muss diesen ein bisschen erraten.

[h1]Charaktere:[/h1]

Es gibt nur zwei Charaktere in der Visual Novel, wovon nur Yumemi grafisch dargestellt wird. Yumemi ist eine sehr sympathische Charakterin, auch wenn sie eigentlich ununterbrochen am Reden ist. Ihr Verhalten ist sonst recht angenehm und nachvollziehbar. Da hat sich auf jeden Fall irgendwer Gedanken gemacht und das merkt man auch.

Der Hauptcharakter ist ein bisschen rabiat, was man bei dem Setting durchaus verstehen kann. Letztendlich wird er dann auch ein bisschen lockerer und mir dadurch auch sympathischer. Sehr gut gefällt mir, dass, auch wenn planetarian recht kurz ist, die Charaktere sich trotzdem nachvollziehbar entwickeln.

[h1]Sound:[/h1]

Von den Charakteren ist nur Yumemi mit der originalen japanischen Stimme ausgestattet. Für meinen Geschmack ist ihre Stimme ein bisschen durchdringend, aber man gewöhnt sich daran.

Die Musik von planetarian ist angenehm. Sie passt eigentlich immer zu dem, was sich gerade abspielt, ist aber auch nicht aufdringlich. Es ist aber nun auch nichts, was einem wirklich lange im Kopf hängen bleibt, so wie es bei anderen Visual Novels bei mir der Fall war.

[h1]Fazit:[/h1]

Obwohl ich kein Fan von Drama bin, hat mir planetarian doch recht gut gefallen. Die Geschichte ist kurz und bündig, prägt sich einem aber dennoch gut ein. In der Kürze liegt die Würze und das macht es auch recht angenehm, die Novel zu lesen. Soweit ich es beurteilen kann ist das englisch der Übersetzung in Ordnung und recht flüssig, ich sehe da keinen Grund zur Beschwerde. 

Mir hat planetarian ~the reverie of a little planet~ auf jeden Fall gefallen, und für Fans einer guten Dramageschichte ist die Visual Novel auf jeden Fall empfehlenswert.

[h1]8/10[/h1]

15650291.review:
key作品『AIR』summer編、『CLANNAD』ことみシナリオ等を手がけたライター、涼元悠一氏の渾身作。
上記作品以前に第10回日本ファンタジーノベル大賞優秀賞を受賞した『青猫の街』では、舞台であるネット社会の様式に合わせて書籍の装丁を左開きの横書きに設定するなど、その作風や構成には人並みならぬこだわりを感じさせる。
実は『ノベルゲームのシナリオ作成技法』なる教科書的著作も上梓されているのだが、その中でも展開のための構成や伏線について重きを置いており、そのこだわりは構成や展開から逆算したキャラクター設定を作るほどだという。そうしたこだわりゆえの遅筆でもあるのだろう。
ともかく彼のテクストには緻密にまとめられた構成の元に織り成される展開が際立っており、それゆえに美しく映える物語に脱帽させられる。

本作は彼の作風の粋が詰まった傑作である。
鬱屈と生きる人間、生気溢れるロボット。
止まない雨の世界、晴れやかな天球世界。
そして二つの天国…
そうした対比や象徴の象るきらめきを余さず詰め込んだ小宇宙劇場をぜひ堪能してほしい。


私はジャスミン（絶賛製作中）の発売を心からお待ちしております。

Трогательная история, умело заключенная в рамки короткой визуальной новеллы.

Купите игру, уделите ей два часа времени из вашего вечера после работы и погрузитесь в мир постапокалипсиса, насквозь промокшего от бесконечного, непрекращающегося ливня. Умирающий мир, где господствуют военные боевые роботы, неуклонно выполняющие свою задачу по уничножению всего живого.

Вам предстоит посетить планетарий - последний, чудом сохранившийся, кусочек повседневной жизни, ушедшей в прошлое. Место, где время остановилось когда-то давно, и где все еще есть искренняя вера в светлое будущее.

Новелла оставит после себя немного тяжелое, меланхоличное настроение, но, тем не менее, запомнится, как добрая, красивая, трогательная история.

15413003.review:
A VN by 'key' and one of the leading VN developers in the world makes a VN that will make you cry at the end, assuming you actually cry because this is VN are by the same people who made Clannad, Air, Kanon, Little Busters (All great VNs and animes). It does show its age (this VN was made 10 years ago) when you play the game and the 'save' function isn't great either, you only get 5 save slots, so you have to overwrite your saves quite a lot. 

The story is set in the future after the "failure of the Space Colonization Program". It is a post-apocalyptic novel involving only 2 main characters [spoiler]"Mr. Customer" aka "The Junker"[/spoiler] and [spoiler]Yumemi Hoshino aka the robot[/spoiler]. There is no "choose your on route/story" in this VN, its a direct story with no choices. 

[h1][b]Graphics[/b][/h1]
As you'd expect, this a pretty old VN, so graphics isn't its strong point here. It has basic drawn images and the animation is limited. Though the visuals are not the great part, you can still enjoy the VN with what is offers. 
[b]Final Score: 5/10[/b]

[h1][b]Storyline[/b][/h1]
This is a VN by 'key' we are talking about, of course its going to tell you a great story. I have never read a VN by 'key' and said "I was disappointed with it". All their VNs are nicely told, it often gives you tears, but that’s part of the experience. Expect to cry in every VN that 'key' makes.
[b]Final Score: 10/10[/b]

[h1][b]Sound[/b][/h1]
Another strong factor here. The music and soundtracks are possibly the most satisfying thing you will love about this VN, considering that it is over 10 years old. I still have a hard time trying to figure out how they managed to make all these soundtracks, they are absolutely fantastic, even though half of them where very sad to listen to. The only downside is that there is only a few of these soundtracks.
[b]Final Score: 9/10[/b]

[h1][b]Gameplay/Features/Layout[/b][/h1]
The VN offers simple controls, press "Enter" to read another line, press "Spacebar" to hide the text box etc...nothing complicated there. The features are also very simple, since the VN is pretty old. It goes the same with the overall layout. Here's and great tip, [h1]tilt your head left or right in the title screen and be amazed[/h1]
[b]Final Score: 6/10[/b]

[h1][b]Price[/b][/h1]
Probably the most common question when buying anything is "Is it worth buying it?". If you like light romance and sad stories. This is your best bet. You won't regret your choice, it was made by 'key', so you know it's worth it. At £7, this is a pretty cheap VN already, considering there are other VNs out there that cost more and has less stuff to offer. This is definitely worth your time and you shouldn't worry about spending too much on this. 
[b]Final Score: 10/10[/b]

[h1][b]Overall Score : 40/50[/b][/h1]
[h1][b]Percentage Score: 80%[/b][/h1]

15016258.review:
This is one of the best stories i've ever had the joy of experiencing.

You might think that an overstatement. But I assure you: the message it presents in the few hours it takes to play/read is masterfully accomplished, and strikes the heart like few works of literature, film or visual novel have.

A regular movie, or a mid-class meal, probably costs close to the $9.99 I paid for this game. Frankly, the amount of emotions I experienced by the end far outweighed the price i've paid for all the movies i've seen in the past three years. It is well worth the buy.

Now, you might ask: what, exactly, makes Planetarian so great?

Answer: the heart of the story, revealed at the climax.

The story is written well, and leads the player through a calm, peaceful, almost nostalgic sense of: i'm about to witness something wonderful. It builds to a semi-climax partway through that's certainly beautiful, but then it moves on and, in an instant, pierces the heart with its true message.

I sincerely hope each player grasps it, as it is a message both beautiful and important for us to remember, as we finish this game and return to our daily lives.

14916033.review:
[i]"Why don't you come to the planetarium? The beautiful twinkling of eternity that will never fade. All the stars in the sky are waiting for you."[/i]

Clocking in at just under 5 hours if you leave auto-read on, planetarian is quite short for a visual novel, but manages to tug quite hard at your heartstrings considering its length. Those of you who have read Key visual novels in the past or watched anime adaptations of them (Clannad, Kanon, Angel Beats, etc.) will know what to expect from planetarian in the emotions department. Those of you that haven't done so, fair warning:

Be prepared to cry. 

Key's works are famous for their tear-jerking properties, and planetarian is no exception.

Getting back to the cold, analytical side of things, planetarian was made back in 2004 - 11 years ago, as of this time of writing. Unfortunately, its age shows a little bit. It's restricted to a 4:3 presentation, so you'll get black bars on the sides of your monitor if you try to go fullscreen.
Unless I didn't dig hard enough, you can't manually set the resolution either, which is annoying, but only that; the resolution that's set is just fine - it's probably whatever resolution the original graphics were meant to appear in - and I never had a need to change the resolution for anything during my run. Thankfully, none of the aforementioned graphical issues really detract from the enjoyment of planetarian, as they're all minor annoyances at best, and understandable ones at that.

The soundtrack is good, though I felt a couple tracks early on were too short considering how long they played. The title theme and "Perfectly Human" in particular stuck out to me as memorable tracks. I can't claim to understand Japanese aside from a few common words and phrases, and the voice acting is entirely in Japanese, so I can't comment on the voice acting much.

I notice a lot of people praise the translation. I can't read the original script, but the translated one felt a little bit stilted to me, as if the translation was purely mechanical, paying no attention to how an ordinary English speaker would normally phrase things. Again, nothing major, just a nitpick.

All in all, planetarian was a short, sweet, touching visual novel that I heartily recommend to anyone, regardless of prior visual novel experience.

But bring tissues.
You'll be using them, trust me.

14495115.review:
It is overall difficult to spoil when the game is so short. If you are still text-impatient, there is also an animated OVA that will cover the entire story. As one of Key's first games, it aged well and there was a quite a bit of concepts that will influence their later development. The post-apocalyptic world setting will resound in the Clannad: After Story, Angel Beats!, and especially Akane and Terra Route of Rewrite. 

The story is a simple one, a junker found a robot in a planetarium that has been long abandoned. In its core, a typical boy-meets-girl story, hopeful but with a bite. The presentation itself is masterful. World design is distinct but not far-reached, creating a mournful and mysterious mood. The strongest point is probably the character design. Both the visual and audio presentation is superb given the amount of interaction with the player. The weariness and indifference of the main character plays a perfect foil to the enthusiam and curiosity of Hoshino Yumemi, the robotic host. 

As short as it is, no words are wasted. Yet there is a slight sense of unsatisfactory:  you would think more robots would be around. Though the desolation was probably crucial to engage the story as a fairy tale of these two. For what it is worth, Planetarian is a bitter-sweet detour. You can quickly become emotionally invested but also quickly become emotionally detached. Compare to key's later work, the build-up is fast and the period of agonizing is rather minmal. Of course the later can leave a deeper mark, but Planetarian will do plenty.

14494884.review:
A must play for fans of any of Key's other works. Planetarian is rather old and lacks features that many newer VN have, but makes up for it with strong charcter devlopment and a well crafted story. If you are not moved by the story after reading to its compleation then you likely are not human. 

10/10 would cry again

14476172.review:
While there were certainly times where I felt the writing was not proceeding down a route that would be considered "good", it always rounded out, and ended up working itself out to be fun and great for character development.  In short, I'm trying to say that, while it may not seem like it at first, the writing works out and is very good throughout the entire 4 hour playthrough.

The 4 hour time that I gave this game is based on reading the game at a normal pace, trying to listen to the voice acting while reading, and possibly spending a few minutes clicking through the CG and Music modes that come with the game.

How does this visual novel score in terms of quality?  Well, writing, characters and story-wise... it's very good.  Heartwarming, even.  I would play it again if I could enjoy stories twice-through, but I'm not that kind of person.

However, visually and technically, this is a very simple, low budget game.  The artwork is very nicely done, but there are VERY few actual scenes within the game, and there is only one character drawn.  There is no animation, and roughly half the game is filled with scenes that are either black or white fills with text.  

None of this should deter anyone looking for a good story, though.  The game delivers, and for $5 or less, it's well worth your money.  Just skip the bag of chips next shopping trip and pick of this game (if on sale or otherwise).

14326985.review:
I thought I was over this VN, only to stumble upon one of its songs months later and feel tears well up in my eyes.
As short as it is, Planetarian presents a thoroughly well-written (albeit not perfectly translated) emotional ride that will not be easy to forget. It never seeks recourse in common anime tropes and stands stoutly on its own writing, as should be the case of any well-executed narrative. This is done to such an extent that the anime art style feels almost inapproriate (but don't take this the wrong way - the anime aesthetic is by no means a failing). Overall, I feel Planetarian is a grossly underappreciated VN that deserves far more success and popularity than it has received. Coming from a scrooge, perhaps the most powerful praise I can give to this game is this: in spite of its short length and lack of any gameplay, I consider paying the full $10 is a perfectly justified purchase.
Should anyone prejudiced against the anime genre somehow find himself reading this review: I urge you to throw away your preconceptions and consider this VN in isolation. If there is ever an exception to be made to the rule, Planetrian is it.

14220104.review:
Planetarian is a relatively short VN (~4 hours) that has no choices for the player to make, instead preferring to tell a set story of its own choosing. While this might bother some since that means that this "game" is little more than a few hours of reading with voices and artwork to go with it, the creators of Planetarian are none other than Key/VisualArts. If you are at all familiar with Key/VisualArts or their other works (notably Kanon, Clannad, and Little Busters!), then you have a pretty good idea what to expect from this: a well-written story, quality artwork, and a deeply emotional conclusion. While Planetarian is tiny compared to Key/VisualArts other VN's (Clannad is at minimum a 50+ hour game, and Little Busters! is about the same size), the quality of their other works ought not to be ashamed by this. In other words, Planetarian is quite good, despite its length and lack of choice.

If you are familiar with Key/VisualArts other works and enjoyed them, then checking this out should be a no-brainer. If you are not however, consider Planetarian a small teaser for what is to come: Clannad will be released on Steam before the year is out (Fall 2015 most likely), and hopefully Key/VisualArts' other works like Kanon or Little Busters! won't be too far behind. Or you can just watch their anime versions if you can't wait that long (I personally recommend Kanon 2006 and Clannad/Clannad After Story for that). Enjoy! :3

14218025.review:
[b][u]Overview[/u]:[/b]

Planetarian: The Reverie of a Little Planet is a short Japanese kinetic visual novel from Key.  Anyone who knows visual novels knows Key.  They are one of the most respected studios out there, known for their amazing characters and touching stories.  Released on Steam just in time for the 10 year anniversary, how does Planetarian hold up?  The short answer?  Quite well.

[b][u]Story[/u]:[/b]

Planetarian is a simple story, set in a post-apocalyptic landscape.  The nature of the harsh world is hinted at throughout the experience, handing out bits and pieces of information regarding the reason for the fall of humanity and the harm we did to our own planet.  Our protagonist is a middle aged man known only as "The Junker."  He is a scavenger.  He lives by finding things to not only maintain his own survival but also by finding things of value within the ruins of humanity and bring them back to the various outposts and villages.  He even had a partner, at least for a while.

The story takes place in one of the "coffin cities," locations of horrible biological and germ warfare.  While avoiding automated war machines and searching for supplies, our protagonist heads deeper into the city interior, towards a dome shaped building.  Initially thinking it might be some type of military instillation he proceeds further only to discover that it is a department store (based off of the Matsubishi Department Store in Hamamatsu) with a planetarium at the top.  It is here that he meets Yumemi and Miss Jena.  What happens?  Who are these two characters?  Find out for yourself.

But to summarize the tale itself is heart breaking and very well written.  It can be a bit wordy at times but I personally feel that is part of the charm.  At a certain point you'll start to feel this sense of dread creeping up your spine and by the time our story reaches the climax and the scenes following you'll be reaching for something to dry your eyes.

[b][u]Visuals[/u]:[/b]

The visuals were beautiful when Planetarian released over ten years ago and they hold up to this date.  The sprites are gorgeous, the backgrounds, while simple, do a fantastic job of painting a bleak picture for a bleak world.  The only major issue I have is the resolution of the resources, which are a result of age, nothing more.  Despite being as old as it is Planetarian still looks great.

[b][u]Sound Design[/u]:[/b]

The music is great.  Fantastic.  Designed to take a back seat to the visuals and the story, the various tracks fit the changing moods well.  At times whimsical and upbeat while or foreboding and downtrodden, it is honestly shocking how well it holds up.

Planetarian also features full voice acting, in Japanese.  The quality once again shows its age but is still well done.

[b][u]System[/u]:[/b]

From a technical standpoint, and remembering the visual novel is more than 10 years old, it is functional but that is about as nice as I can be.  The font is...readable and everything functions the way it should...but it is old and it shows it.  Upon completion you will unlock the CG Gallery and Music Gallery.  They're expected but still nice little treats.


[b][u]Conclusion[/u]:[/b]

Is Planetarian: The Reverie of a Little Planet worth your time and money?  Absolutely.  It is a classic of the visual novel medium, the perfect length for the story it sets out to tell, and to this day still beautifully haunting.

14137770.review:
This is a beautiful and tragic story. You will cry. No really, I don't care if you're a hardened badass, if you honestly sit down and invest yourself in this story you will cry. 

This is my first time ever experiencing a kenetic novel and only the second visual novel. This is a much more powerful format then I originally thought and I'm sad that I haven't been looking at them more seriously until now. 

Since theres already a lot of reviews helpful to those who are familier with the format and those explaining the story, I'm going to be talking to people who don't 'do' visual novel games. I was very skeptical of the format. I didn't see anything about them other then the taste-less demodisks sometimes toted around large conventions. You know the type I'm talking about. Please, give this style of game a chance. Between this game and Hatoful Boyfriend, I was shown this style in the light it was truly ment to be in. 

This game isn't quite a book but it's not a game in the traditional sense. It's a game in the same way Dear Ester is a game. It's not about choices, theres no puzzles or combat. It's an experience, it's a story, and it's brillient at delivering that story. There is text to read, like a traditional novel, but the music helps set the tone like a movie would and the visuals help to really feel connected to the characters, both the one you 'play' as and Yumemi, the robot girl you meet. 

Like I said before, the game has an overall sad tone. If that's a problem for you, for whatever reason, I would understand you skipping this title. If you think you'll be okay though, PLEASE, do yourself a favor. Buy this game. Sit back and enjoy it. The whole thing in one sitting might take... oh 4 hours or so. If you can't do it all in one sitting theres a save function. 

Just... just give it a try. 

All the stars in the sky are waiting for you.

14067827.review:
Planetarian is kinetic visual novel, meaning that it is completely linear and there are no choices involved. I would like to point out that it is also the first VN I have ever completed.
This novel revolves around the main character, a "Junker" who scavanges the wastes of this post-apocalyptic world, and a robot named Yumemi who was created to work at a planetarium that has now been abandoned for nearly 30 years.
It is a fairly short story, however it still manages to go into keen depth on the back-stories of the characters and the world they live in. Moreover, this novel has some very heartwarming moments, as well as some absolutely heartwrenching ones, which is to be expected from the legendary VisualArts/Key, creators of some of the best VNs (and anime) of all time.

This story will make you laugh, it will make you cry, but most importantly of all, it will tell you an excellent story of a man and a robot, in a very well realized "Fallout-esque" world.
I would heartily reccomend it, and as someone who has only ever finished this VN, I can say that it is an excellent entry into the genre, as it left me with the want for more of its kind.

14064365.review:
[h1]"Why don't you come to the planetrium? 
The beautiful twinkling of eternity that will never fade, no matter what."[/h1]

Planetarian ~the reverie of a little planet~ is a true masterpiece of storytelling and one of the best visual I have ever had the pleasure of reading. It was develped by [i] VisualArt's/Key[/i] who has won my deepest respect are [i]CLANNAD, AIR, Kanon, and Angel Beats!.[/i] Reading Planetarian has taken me a Feel-trip rollercoaster, swirling my emotions and possibly giving me a reason to enjoy the life i have from the depiction of Planetarian's world. 

[h1]"Because the point of the War was no longer the conquets of land;
it had become nothing more than the internecine creed of revenge and massacre"[/h1]

The set story and the emotions displayed throughout it, make this a visual novel worth reading. The story depicts Humanity's biggest mistakes. They have shotgunned theirself in the foot, and now the tiny fabrics of what is left only tells us how far we have distroyed ourself. For those who well still alive, apathy and selfishness fills their hearts. Survival seems to be the only real key of extence. 
Humanity has fallen from grace. 
It's something we can relate to, like that of the Cold Wars. A scary time where we coud have destoyed ourselfs. The threat was real, and it has been depicted muliple times again of the horrid results of our actions. Planetarian is an example of it.
The world in Planetarian is a dark and ugly place. Why would it be that this story touched my heart? The key word is simple: [b]Hope{/b].  Hope that came from a bubbly [spoiler]robot[/spoiler]and apatheic Junker, Yumemi and 'Mr. Cutsomer'

[h1]"Please do not divide Heaven in two."
"That is my prayer to the God of Robots."[/h1]

The characters of our story were easy to fall in love with. Hoshino Yumemi, our planetarian [spoiler]Robot[/spoiler], gave of us joy for her undieing love to teach people about the stars. Set in a time where she could not comprehend, Yumemi uplifts the spirit to your character and channels happiness through her bubbly attitude. 
Your main character, 'Mr. Customer', sets the reality of the story and how humanity has met its tragic fate. He is set in a time with no law or any real social establishment. As a Junker only for means to make ends-meat, Mr. Customer wonders into an uninhabitable city looting for supplies and something worth bartering. His initial scavage into the city seems like a big waste, but finds something worth more valuable to him than any cigarettes or booze could ever be. 
'Mr. Customer' was nothing more than an apathetic Junker at the beginning, but grows to love and cherish the memories of Yumemi.

[h1]"Mankind will be able to solve all its problems, and one day reach out to the world of the stars."[/h1]

Planetarian is nothing but an inspiring story of hopes and dreams of something better for a ravaged world. A world torn to pieces that affect our main character, 'Mr. Customer', but he finds his piece of salvation from our loving Planetarian, Yumemi. 
If you have never read a visual novel in your life and want to read something dramatically touching, Planetarian ~the reverie of a little planet~ is for you. There will be moments of bitter happiness, laughter, and saddness as you read.
It's a beautiful story. 
A story that only [i]VisualArt's/Key[/i] could ever write. 

[h1]"All the stars in the sky are waiting for you."[/h1]

14043172.review:
I don't usually write reviews, but in this case I feel I have to.

Planetarian is an amazing visual novels. While it has no choices, and is quite short compared to other Key works, but it still manages to capture one's imagination and give a thrilling emotional experience.

Usually I personally avoid Visual novels without choices, but Planetarian has definitely proven that they can still telle an amazing story and engage you in the world.

This is not a game, but it doesn't need to be one to be fun and engaging.
Visual novels are in many ways like a mix between a book and a movie (And in some cases a game, but not in this case). It is personal like a book, but it is also vivid, engaging and visually stimulating like a movie.

I strongly recommend Planetarian, especially for someone who is curious about Visual novels, as this perfectly captures how wonderful they are, assuming you immerse yourself and take the time to play it.

I can only say two things about the actual story without giving spoilers. First, it is very well delivered and memorable. Second, you WILL cry. 13925624.review:
You will play it, and you will feel it.
If you can't feel it, play it again. If you've played it again and still don't feel it.
You Monster.

On a more less serious note.
This is a Visual Novel through and through, so keep that in mind.
The story is a lovely different take on the "AI of the future" concept, you remember they saying "In the future, AIs will destroy humans"? Yes, the story has that, but it also explored the other side, where an AI will faithfully follow humans, the main character is the embodiment of that.

The music is always nice and soothing, sometimes carry a tune of cheerfulness, sometimes a hint of melancholy and sadness, it's simply wonderful.

The art is cute, of course, but express the tone of the story very well, I find the contrast between Yumemi (the man character) and everything surrounds her a good representation of the tone of the story.

Key has never disappoint with their Visual Novels, no matter which one I look at, I can't find a reason to not like it, this is why I hate them, they always bring along the Rain with them.
If you don't mind reading, you may find this story making your heart skip a beat, and I wish upon a star that it will.

13911655.review:
[b] "Won't you come to the planetarium?" [/b]

Disclaimer: This is a "kinetic novel", in which you don't get to make any choices. There is only one route and one ending, and you progress simply by reading through the story. If you're looking for a 'visual novel' with choices and multiple endings, this may not be for you. Still, Planetarian presents a good story that's well worth the price.

I've heard about this game for a while. "It's a story that'll make you cry!" they said. Well, I've never cried after watching movies/reading stories/playing games, but Planetarian got me real close to that.

I won't talk about the story, since the story IS short. If you want a non-spoilery blurb about what this game is about, the description in the "About This Game" segment is good enough. What I can say is that even if you saw through the tricks and predicted the ending to varying degrees of accuracy (like I did), the delivery is done well enough to still be impactful, for me at least.

The voice-acting in the game, as I understand it, was added for the PS2 release and is featured here. It's in Japanese, but visual novel enthusiasts probably wouldn't mind. Hoshino Yumemi, the robot girl, is voiced rather well. Her voice actor doesn't seem to do much work outside of visual novels though. However, the Junker, who narrates the story, is voiced by famous voice actor Daisuke Ono. He doesn't have a lot of lines, but they were delivered well.

I'm not too familiar with Key or VisualArt, but the art is done quite well, and I say this about the CGs, backgrounds, and Yumemi's design herself. While her face is nothing distinctly unique, at least she doesn't come with the weird eyes that the characters in CLANNAD came to be known for. Plus, her costume design is quite unique.

Overall, Planetarian is a good kinetic novel. I can recommend it for those seeking to try out reading visual novels, or someone who's looking for a story to read to pass 2-3 hours. It's not the BEST written work out there, but it's still an emotional, beautiful work.

13910432.review:
<이 게임은 비공식 한글패치가 있습니다>

key에서 만든 게임이니 스토리는 걱정할 필요 없을 듯 하고, 실제로 스토리는 애잔하면서 슬픈 느낌이 잘 전달되었다. 비주얼 노벨은 텍스트 중심이 되기 때문에 CG, 음악, 보이스 같은 것이 잘 갖춰지지 않을 경우 상당히 지루해질 수 있는데, 이 게임은 CG가 약간 부족하다는 느낌을 제외하면 다른 면에선 전혀 밀리는게 없다. CG 중 히로인의 CG가 너무 부족한 것이 큰 단점이긴 하지만, 스토리가 워낙 좋기 때문에 그 단점이 충분히 커버 된다.(아니면 내가 이 게임의 히로인, "호시노 유메미"에게 단단히 콩깍지가 씌였거나...)

어쨌든 개인적으론 크게 만족한 게임. 그러니까 key! 어서 빨리 다른 게임도 스팀에 팔란 말이다!

13907064.review:
=====================================
注意, 该游戏为《星之梦》的十周年纪念版, 与原版不同, 该版本不存在汉化补丁!
如果你是首次接触这款游戏, 并且不会英语/日语, 需要在购买游戏后下载一份汉化过的盗版原版游戏进行游玩.
=====================================

在这充满悲伤的绝望世界里, 诞生了一个小小的故事, 故事里的二人, 在这崩溃的世界中, 互相依偎, 追寻着希望.

这是Key社带给我们的童话故事, 故事中人物的对话过于温柔, 溢着小小的温暖, 可这笔墨所描绘出的世界却是如此残酷, 冰冷的寒气吸入肺中便能使人颤栗不止, 仿佛连那最后一丝温暖也会在下一刻散去. 凉元悠一精湛的脚本为《星之梦》所塑造出的这种无力感, 让人欲罢不能, 我们早已知道一切将以悲伤结尾, 却无力作出抗争.

玩游戏时我总在想, 一款游戏能为玩家带来什么, 对这部作品而言, 它没有为我带来Key社一贯的催泪弹效果, 却带给了我一份对于人类本身过于沉重的思考. 游戏能给予人反省, 便已超越了它形式上的价值, 愿每一位玩家, 都能在《星之梦》中, 有所触动, 有所感悟.

13888533.review:
This is a short Visual Novel with no choices.  Don't think of it as a game; it's a short story, with pictures and music.

But what a beautiful, bittersweet, short story it is.  Set in the remnants of a city after bio-warfare has mostly wiped the human race from the planet, the story is about a Junker--someone who sneaks into cities, past automated defenses left over from previous wars--in the hopes of finding food, weapons, or useful materials.  Instead, he finds a robot, a greeter at a planetarium, miraculously still functioning.  What unfolds is a tale about the importance of our hopes and dreams, even in the face of great despair.

Planetarian will take about 2-3 hours to read.  If that doesn't seem like it's worth $10 to you, then wait for it to go on sale.  But by all means, read it.

13825296.review:
Touching little story, about the length of a couple average movies.  The art and music are serviceable, but not spectacular; as a visual novel with no decision points, there is no gameplay whatsoever, and the only replay value is whatever you'd get out of reading the same story twice.

The star of the show, which made it well worth the price I paid on sale, is, of course, the writing.  The prose is beautiful, the setting draws you in, and the characterization and dialogue are great.  Then there's the story--the story will give you mega-feels.  I promise.

13818188.review:
Planetarian ~the reverie of a little planet~ was quite short visual novel compared to others (only 5 hours long) but it was a sad one.
It didn't end happily it ended right at Hoshino Yumemi's death while there were death warmongers incoming to his location.
In a post-apocalyptic world there was nothing left after the 30 year war, only ruins and few survivor scavengers and Death bots made by humans themselves.
Overpopulation and depletion of natural resources lead the world to a nuclear war and destroyed half of the humanity, then after a year it was halved and again and again and again.
Until there were very little people left and struggling to even just survive.
Big powers who started the war didn't exist anymore.
Then, the rain started which did not end, killing even more people.
It poisoned plants, making it impossible to farm food and even killing the man made bacteria.
Trying to live in mars failed to succeed as it was found not habitable.
The chance for humankind to survive are slim.
The soundtrack of this game is amazing just listen to this track http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9AyD22po4SI
It perfectly fits the story.

To conclude, this game is amazing visual novel made by KEY.
And I recommend buying this visual novel.

13774854.review:
Games like this definitely aren't for everyone, but if you enjoy reading, it is most definitely for you. This is the story of an android, and her first customer in nearly thirty years. Like any great novel, or peice of literarure, it has ups and downs. Times you're laughing, times you're angry, and, of course, times you're crying. I think that this would make a great introduction in to the world of Visual Novels (VNs), or another good read for those who play them regularly. Planetarian is of course a bit different from most VNs, as there is no branching paths in the story. We call ones like these Kinetic. In any case, I felt it was a bit expensive for only about five hours of reading. My advise would be to wait until it is on sale, or try a few free VNs, like Juniper's Knot by Dischan Media, another Knetic novel like this. 

I'm gonna give this a 9/10. The only obsticle to really manage is that the only options you get are when you open it. If you want to change any settings, you have to right click. To be completely honest, it took about t a half-hour of reading to figure that out :/

13766324.review:
I have no shame in admiting when a game is sad enough to make make me misty eyed. This has happened quite a bit in recent years. It's a bit rarer when tears are shed, I can only think of 2 games in recent memory that have caused me to cry: To the Moon and Virtue's Last Reward. 

This game, however, is the first time I've ever had to take a break in order to calm myself down. This game tugs at the heartstrings throughout, but the ending in particular is so sad that I have trouble thinking that anyone can read it without tears shed. 

If you have any passing interest in Visual Novels, then I highly HIGHLY recommend this one. It's quite short, but very much worth your time.

This visual novel deals with a man in a futuristic post-apocalyptic world, trying to scavage whatever he can from a deserted city. In the deserted city he happens to come across a planetarium and a robot which used to work in it.

However, a visual novel may not be for everyone: do not expect to be making decisions, moving in a 2D or 3D environment or a cinematic experience, as you won't find it here. 13732454.review:
During my early years in college, I began to experiment with games from the other side of the world-those being japanese games. This endeavour was purely boredom at first, but I was soon able to draw some interesting conclusions. Personally, I have found japanese games to be superior in terms of story and music, whereas western games still hold the reigns in the gameplay and especially the graphical departments. Planetarian is no exception.

Planeterian is a game created by the company Key, who is more well known of creating visual novels which form the basis of animes such as Kanon, Air, and Clannad. Known for creating the nakige or "crying game" genre, Key specializes in tearing hearts and ripping them to shreds. This company has a unique expertise of creating the most "feels" you will ever feel. If you thought the notebook or titanic was touching, I can't even begin to imagine the physical breakdown you will have from playing games such as these. Especially the anime "Clannad After Story", which covers the life of a man from highschool-28 years old and themes such as fatherhood, change and maturity, and is the only fictional work that has ever made me shed a tear. Planetarian will most likely have a large enough impact to force you to tear up, although arguably it is not as sad as some of Key's other stuff.

Planetarian itself is a short game, which can be approximately finished over 2 nights. It is a kinetic novel-one in which players read text without choices...much like a choose your adventure type of thing. The emphasis here is the story-the game takes place in a post-apocalyptic world, where a middle-aged man finds an abandoned service robot in a planetarian, or a theatre where one views the stars. I can't go into much detail about the plot, but let's say it is very typical of a Key game. The plot is albeit slow paced at the start, but the ending sure makes up for it.

The high composition quality of the music is immediately apparent when you start the game. There's not that many tracks because it is a very short game, but the music sets the mood extremely well  (especially the menu theme, aka Gentle Jena). The composers really outdid themselves in this game.

The graphics...well I'm not a huge fan of the whole anime artstyle thing, but hey if that's your kind of thing (to fap to?) you'll feel right at home. Again though, the focus of these games is on plot, and the visuals appropriately set the atmosphere and help with giving context.

Would I recommend this game to most people? Hard to say. I can see people getting bored pretty easily, but if you have the patience to play this game to the end and have some heart/even slightly touched by tragic stuff, then you'll find a hidden gem that you will not find anywhere else in the steam library, or even dare I say out of all videogames. You'll remember this one for years to come...just remember to bring a tissue box.

13679780.review:
[h1]A Short and Enjoyable Kinetic Novel That May Not Be For Everyone[/h1]

[i]planetarian ~the reverie of a little planet~[/i] was wonderful, touching story that kept me captivated thoughout, and I enjoyed it immensely. It is exactly what I would have expected from a studio as good as Key. However, that does [i]not[/i] mean that [i]planetarian ~the reverie of a little planet~[/i] is a title that everyone would enjoy, and as such, makes it a hard game to recommend fully.

Firstly, to those who are not aware of the concept of [b]visual/kinetic novels[/b], this game is [b]purely story based[/b], and there are [b]little to no real gameplay elements[/b] to be found. You follow the story being told to you from start to finish, and that's really all there is to it.

Extending on that, this game is also what is known as a [b]'Kinetic Novel'[/b]. This differs from a visual novel in the sense that there are [b]no choices[/b] to be made at any point during the story, and the story follows [b]a single, linear path[/b]. As such, the game is an [b]excellent starting point[/b] for those looking to delve into the world of visual novels.

The story is also [b]relatively short[/b]. I completed the story in just over 5 hours using auto-read on the default setting. This also adds onto my point of this being a good starting point for people looking to get into this genre, as visual novels can easily take over 50 hours of game time to complete during a first playthrough.

I bought this game knowing what I was getting into. I simply wanted to enjoy a good story, and that is exactly what I got. However, if you are expecting to find amazing gameplay and stunning graphics, then this most definitely is [b]NOT[/b] the type of title for you.

13611323.review:
Genre: Sci-fi/Drama
Duration: About 4 hours
Developed by: Key
Licensed by: Sekai Project

Once you, the unnamed protagonist, reach the planetarium in a sarcophagus city, you meet this girl robot Yumemi. She talks a lot and insists in giving you a bouquet of junk. I like to refer to the protagonist as Mr. Customer, as that's how Yumemi refers to you. In any case, Planetarian spends a considerable amount of time explaining what has happened to the world and how desolate it is.
 
Years ago, a full-scale war devastated Earth. Mankind built robots that could keep on identifying enemies and killing them even after all humans were decimated. And, indeed, human population decreased severely, to the point now there are only a few settlements left, far away from what we used to call "cities" back then. Some of said cities became sarcophagi, isolated and supposedly full of resources now rare in the few junkers who dare to trespass their walls' daily lives. The only two things that are constant in a human life now are fear and the rain.

The Rain is some sort of a third character. The war, in the end, doesn't matter; the destruction doesn't matter; the booby trap that killed the protagonist's partner some time ago doesn't matter - but the fact that there's an ever-present toxic downpour is very much stressed by the artwork and the text, since, after all, it's the solid representation of the misery the world is going through. What is the Rain like? It (or she, since "rain" is a feminine noun in Portuguese and I can't help but think of a rain as a feminine entity) is negative. Inexorably, unchangeably, untouchably so. She will not stop, she will not break, she will not waver. However, Mr. Customer learned how to live with her.
 
So you, the player, transit between two worlds: the barren outside, reigned over by the Rain, and the barren inside of the planetarium, reigned over by Yumemi. She knows every inch of the building. She's a robot, responsible for the planetarium. And what is she like? She is positive. Inexorably, unchangeably, untouchably so. She is a robot, programmed to be like this, yet "just a little broken". She cannot stop, she cannot break, she cannot waver. However, Mr. Customer learns how to live with her.
 
What is the relationship between these two characters? None. They are completely unaware of one another and the protagonist is the bridge. It is confusing for Mr. Customer and it is confusing for you. The fact that you are the 2,500,000th customer (or, rather, the 2,497,290th customer, or rather rather, 2,497,288th visitor I think) is the whole reason why the story unfolds. She is not a human, there are never second intentions to what she says. She is what she is. She is the same as the Rain - they are two entities that can't ever touch because they are inexorable and will not, by essence and definition, change how they think and what they do.
 
So the story is about Yumemi and the Rain, or, rather, about the time you'll spend alongside an upbeat, bright, fun to listen to and just a little broken robot who thinks of the pernicious, toxic rain outside as  "an unfortunate weather", day by day. You're a bystander, yet you're the reason why the story unfolds. This is how planetarian ~reverie of a little planet~ drags you into its world and makes you deeply attached to a character, even without choices. Especially without choices.

Positive:

*It is one of the most touching stories on Steam. In fact, it's one of the most touching visual novels ever.

Negative: 

*Might be expensive

Сюжет просто прекрасен, что еще можно ожидать от [b]VisualArt's/Key[/b]. Несмотря на всю комичность той леди, все же это драма. По ходу прохождения мы узнаем о нелегкой судьбе обоих героев, о их мыслях по поводу своего места, будущего и настоящего. 13484643.review:
So... I don't normally write reviews... But I feel that this one deserves one.. 

So.. First off.. This game is a Kinetic Novel.
A kinetic novel is a VN that does not present the "player" with any choices at all; they simply read through a single unbranching story. (Credits to VNDB.org)
Which means.. You don't get to make a choice in this game. So there's only one ending. And this game is really really short. I finished it in about... 70minutes.. So, if your willing to buy the game despite it being very short, then continue to read this review for its pros and cons~

Pros
- This game has great OST inside, and can get you emotional at a point of the game.
- Great art
- Great Character development ( Main Protagonist gets a change of heart , robot girl that warms your heart )

Cons
- The game is short (About longest 2hrs and your done with the game.)

Buying this game is probably more for supporting the publishers. If you want to support the game, then buy it.

So, heres the story, I don't usually read kinetic novels nor play games of the similiar kind. My friend gifted this to me. And I thought I knew what to expect. I did not.

This isn't a game, thats the first thing. No choices, no multiple endings. You progress by reading text. That's all there is

Graphic wise, it isn't as "modern" nor as intricate as most modern Visual novels and/or animations. But its enough for most of the time.  The writing though is superb. Its quite a change of pace for me who plays [i]fast-paced[/i] games.

The music is really good for its time, hopefully it still is now. At least I think that way.

Cmon, for many Visual Novel readers, obviously, "KEY" is a group well know for their novels. This one of them.

So heres my recommendation.

If you are neck deep into visual novels that have multiple endings, multiple characters, multiple choice. This might not be your cup of tea, but then again, this IS [i]Key[/i] we're talking about.

But if you want a change of pace, a relaxing trip of feels, then "planetarian ~the reverie of a little planet~" might be just for you.


On a less serious note,

I rate it "I need a hug" out of 10

13100167.review:
I didn't cry when my nan died. I didn't cry when my pets died. I didn't cry when any of my girlfriends left me (most of them left because I never show emotions).

This game had me bawling my eyes out for two hours solid, and ten years after playing it for the first time, I still choke up every time I think about it. Not just the sad parts -- I wept with joy at the happy parts. I laughed till I cried at the funny parts. I overflowed with awe at the beautiful parts.

If you are a cold hearted emotionless robot of a person, and you wonder what it must be like to be a normal person who feels things, I recommend reading this story to find out. If you are a normal person, I recommend it too, and I also recommend a large stack of tissues to help you see the screen once the story gets going.

I am fairly sure that nobody will ever create a kinetic novel which is similar to this and better than it, so even if it doesn't sound interesting to you, I'd say play it anyway just to see what a tiny shard of perfection looks like.

13085541.review:
This visual novel is a true display of how amazing visual novels can be.
The visuals and artwork are beautifully crafted down to every last detail, from the character art to the backgrounds, everything is perfectly defined, a masterpiece of modern Japanese anime art.

Sound is equally brilliant, from the voice acting down to the music, every word, every tone, every little tune is perfectly placed and fits equisitely with the mood throughout.

And of course, the main part of a visual novel, the story.  What can I say about the story?  Well...

Planterian, in short, is one of the most emotionally powerful things I've ever experienced in my life.  I'm accustomed to visual novels and their abilities to create an emotional response, whether it's happiness, sadness, anger or any other range of emotions, but what I didn't expect from this was that it would have me crying so much that I felt like my eyeballs were going to explode because my tear ducts couldn't excrete tears fast enough to keep up with what was going on.  It's a real heart-breaker of a story, and at the end you won't feel like you're just losing another character in another game, you'll feel like you're losing a much loved friend, it'll shatter your heart into a million pieces and scatter them across the night sky like the twinkling stars of Yumemi's planetarium.  It's worth more than the price it's selling for on Steam, and I recommend that anyone, whether you like visual novels or not, should sit down with this, switch it on auto, get a box of tissues, and prepare to witness something that will stay in your heart and your memories forever. x
